sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÉC unless otherwise noted.

div.head: Replace with your title.
div.p: Replace with your text.BRitannie (called in tyme paſt Aymoyica) bordereth eaſtward vpon the country of Maine and aparre of Anics, towards the north it harth the narrow ſea & aparre of the country of Conſtantin, towards the weſt the maine Ocean, & towards the ſouth the country of Peiten. indent] It is reconed in two partes, to wit the higher & the lower Britany. [indent] There are in it nyne Biſhoprykes which are deuided into three diſtinche quarters. [indent] Three of theſe which are, Cornnoille, S. Paul & Treguiers, do ſpeake the Britiſh tongue, & the inhabitants are called Cornabians, Other three, to wit,thoſe of Dol, Renes & S. Male i do ſppeak the French tongue.[indent] The third beeing thoſe of Nantes, vonnes and S.Brien, do ſpeake the French and Britiſh. [indent] The principall townes in Britannie are Namtes and Renes, but in Reues reſydeth the courre of Parlament for the whole prouince. [indent] the chief hauen of all Britany is that of Breſt. [indent] It is not to bee omitted that the hauen of S. Male is garded with siaſtiues, which beeing therero trayned do there kepe diligent night warch. [indent] It is generally a pleaſant & fertile country, the earable land beeing as good as can be deſyred, hauing alfoplenty of wood & paſture, & exceeding great ſtore of medow ground. [indent] There are in it mynes of Iran & lead, & in ſome-places ſilucr. [indent] ſyne ſalt is there boyled through the heat of the Sun. [indent] And the country through the many comodiries thereof, & the ſea rrafike, is very welthy.
